Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Advanced Computing Cluster for General Relativistic Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the acquisition of a 600-core, high-speed, large-memory computer cluster, "BlueSky", dedicated to supporting interdisciplinary research at the frontiers of gravitational physics, relativistic astrophysics, advanced high-performance computation, and scientific visualization in the Center for Computational Relativity and Gravitation at the Rochester Institute of Technology. Research will focus on some of the most extreme phenomena in the universe, where the strongest gravitational and magnetic fields interact with ultra-relativistic matter and high-energy radiation, that can only be studied through advanced, large-scale computation and visualization. These includes: (1) calculation of accurate gravitational wave signals from intermediate-mass ratio, highly-spinning black-hole binary inspirals and mergers, (2) the development of a highly accurate General Relativistic Magnetohydrodynamics code (which will be made publicly available through the Einstein Toolkit Consortium) for the modeling of neutron star mergers, accretion disks, and core-collapse supernovae, (3) calculation of electromagnetic signals from merging supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies. Our research will use the enhanced speed of GPUs to generate fast and accurate hybrid gravitational signatures for LIGO data analysis.

Research training will involve students across several programs and colleges at RIT. Visualizations will be used for enhancing the classroom experience of deaf and hard-of-hearing students in RIT's National Technical Institute for the Deaf and out-of-class educational activities. The cluster will be housed in the CCRG "Black-Hole" Lab. The laboratory is cooled using a state-of-the-art, in-rack, green-cooling solution provided by OptiCool Technologies. The laboratory has large glass walls along a high-traffic corridor, making the cluster and its operation highly visible to the public. Seeing "BlueSky" will stimulate interest in the instrument itself, gravitational physics, astrophysics in general, and green technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funds from this grant were used to purchase the BlueSky cluster at the Rochester Institute of Technology. BlueSky consists of 50 Sandy Bridge nodes with 16 computational cores per node and 20 Nehalem nodes with 12 computational cores per node. The nodes are interconnected with a QDR Infiniband network.  The BlueSky cluster is cooled with a unique in-rack cooling solution developed by Opticool Technologies of Rochester, New York. The cluster is used to highlight this cooling solution to the general public and promote green computing.  CCRG researchers have made it a centerpiece of outreach efforts to visiting students, including a number of groups representing high school students from underserved communities participating in other RIT programs.

BlueSky has been used over the past three years to explore fundamental issues in General Relativity and Relativistic astrophysics. This includes gravitational recoil that can cause the merger remnant of a supermassive black hole binary merger to recoil at thousands of kilometers per second, modeling the dynamics of nearly extremal black holes, and modeling electromagnetic signatures from black hole mergers. One of the primary goals of the research performed on BlueSky is the modeling of gravitational radiation from the mergers of black holes for use by the NSF-funded LIGO project.  It has also been used for code design and testing related to the Einstein Toolkit, an NSF-funded project that designs, builds, and maintains the largest and most widely used publicly available code for performing numerical relativistic simulations.

Research enabled by the cluster was also used in the development of an innovative education program "AstroDance", which combined dance and scientific visualization to connect deaf and hard of hearing students with astrophysical phenomena.  It forms a key component of a presentation made by the CCRG at ``ImagineRIT'', an annual public event on the RIT campus that draws in over 10,000 visitors. A short film about "Center for Computational Relativity and Gravitation" was also created this year to promote gravitational wave research and the study of black hole astrophysics done on the cluster. This film was shown at the APS March and April meetings this year, is available on youtube, and is used by RIT to promote STEM education and research.
